Prof. Qi received his B.S. in environmental chemistry from Nankai University in 1998, and Ph.D. in environmental science from Nankai University in 2003. He worked as a JSPS Postdoctoral Fellow at Tohoku University (Sendai, Japan) from Oct. 2006 to Nov 2010. He was promoted to a full professor in 2011 at Nankai University. His research interest mainly focuses on green processes for the production of value-added materials and chemicals from organic solid wastes. He has published more than 160 peer reviewed scientific papers, and these papers have been cited over 6300 times with H index 44. He also has co-authored over 20 patents, 5 books and 3 book chapters on environmental engineering and biomass resources utilization. His research work has been awarded 2 items of first-class prizes and 1 item of second-class prizes of provincial and ministerial level. Prof. Qi has been selected as leading talent in the National Ten Thousand Talents Plan, Shennong Talent Plan from Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, and was supported by the Outstanding Youth Science Foundation of Tianjin. This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 22178181), the Natural Science Fund of Tianjin (No. 21JCZDJC00180) and the Fundamental Research Funds for Review Upcycling of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics via electrocatalysis Haoye Wang Writing – original draft Validation Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Richard Lee Smith Jr Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision b Xinhua Qi Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nankai University, Tianjin 300350, China College of Environmental Science and Engineering Nankai University Tianjin 300350 China College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nankai University, Tianjin 300350, China b Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8572, Japan Graduate School of Environmental Studies Tohoku University Sendai 980-8572 Japan Graduate School of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8572, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This review provides an overview of the progress for upgrading and recycling monomers derived from waste polyester plastics into high-value chemicals through electrocatalytic technology. Electrocatalysis offers efficient and targeted conversion of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics to chemical products under ambient temperature and pressure conditions. This review provides analysis of research on electrochemical upgrading of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics published from 2021 to present. Factors for assessing upgrading of waste polyester plastics include alkaline hydrolysis pretreatment, indices of electrochemical reaction process (activity, stability, and techno-economic analysis), separation, and product recovery. Types of depolymerization monomers and their value-added products are summarized along with electrocatalytic mechanisms and reaction pathways. Notably, cathode coupled reactions offer significant value for anodic waste plastic oxidation during electrolysis processes. Development of bifunctional electrocatalysts can reduce the cost of coupled systems and complexity of the electrolyzer. Upgrading and recycling of waste plastic monomers using electrocatalytic technology should undergo downstream processing to form high-value products containing C–N and C–S derived functional groups obtained from depolymerized monomers. Electrochemical conversion and upgrading of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics can contribute to industrialization and global economies and help to realize environmental sustainability. Keywords Waste plastics Monomer Electrocatalysis Value-added products Upgrade recycling Coupling reaction Abbreviations AA adipic acid BDO 1,4-butanediol BOR 1,4-butanediol oxidation reaction CO2RR carbon dioxide reduction reaction CV cyclic voltammetry CA chronoamperometry CP chronopotentiometry DFT density functional theory EG ethylene glycol EE energy efficiency EGOR ethylene glycol oxidation reaction EIS electrochemical impedance spectroscopy FE faraday efficiency FA formic acid FT-IR Fourier transform infra-red GA glycolic acid Hac acetic acid HER hydrogen evolution reaction HPLC high-performance liquid chromatography KDF potassium diformate LSV linear sweep voltammetry LA lactic acid MEA membrane electrode assembly MA maleic acid NMR nuclear magnetic resonance NO3RR nitrate reduction reaction ORR oxygen reduction reaction OER oxygen evolution reaction PET polyethylene terephthalate PLA polylactic acid PBT polybutylene terephthalate PBAT poly (butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) PBS polybutylene succinate TPA terephthalic acid TEA techno-economic analysis SA succinic acid 1 Introduction As multi-functional materials, plastics are widely used in packaging, textiles, construction, and transportation due to their desirable physical properties that include lightweightness, strong plasticity, high flexibility, chemical inertness, recyclability, and low cost. To date, global production of plastics has exceeded 8 billion tons with an annual output approaching 400 million tons [1,2]. Despite plastics bringing great convenience into people’s lives, plastic waste has become a serious issue with only about 9% being recycled, while the remainder is incinerated, landfilled, or discarded into the environment [3]. Consequently, microplastics, which are formed by the partial decomposition of polymeric materials and plastic wastes, are threatening human life and health through their entry into the food chain and water supply [4–6]. Moreover, improper disposal or recycling of plastic wastes made from fossil-based chemicals has the consequence of wasteful resource use. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop strategies that can effectively treat and recycle plastics and plastic wastes. Conventional methods for dealing with plastic wastes include landfilling, incineration, and mechanical recycling [7]. Of these, landfilling and incineration methods for plastic wastes disposal will cause certain harm to the environment, such as groundwater pollution, the generation of harmful chemicals, and the increase of carbon emissions that further exacerbate global warming [8–11]. In contrast, plastic recycling provides a strategy of “waste to value” by producing useful chemical products, thereby promoting sustainable development and management [8]. Mechanical recycling, also known as secondary recycling, involves reprocessing used plastics to create new, sometimes similar, products [12]. Common mechanical recycling methods involve physical processes such as extrusion, crushing, and shredding, which may seem to be green and environmental, while mechanical reprocessing operations are not cost-effective as a general strategy [13]. To enhance the value of plastics, chemical upgrading of spent polymeric materials into high-value products has attracted much attention. Thermal and chemical upgrading of plastics into value-added products via pyrolysis, hydrogenolysis, catalysis, or microwave treatment methods is proven technologies, although their application may require use of high-temperatures or high-pressures which lead to issues in energy consumption, solids handling, gas emissions, or liquid wastes. Biocatalysis, photocatalysis, and electrocatalysis are being explored as sustainable alternatives to thermal catalytic methods [14]. Electrocatalysis can use renewable energy sources (such as wind, solar, and tidal energy) as the source of required electrical energy to offer the possibility of converting and upgrading waste plastics under ambient temperature and pressure conditions, thereby eliminating extreme temperature and pressure conditions required for thermal catalysis, making the whole process environmentally sustainable and in line with the principles of green chemistry. Further, modular design of the electrolysis system not only allows the reaction system to be linearly scaled up or down but also enhances substrate conversion rate and product selectivity through control of electrolysis parameters [15–18]. However, due to the inertness of plastics and their limited solubility in aqueous electrolytes, they rarely participate directly in redox reactions occurring on the electrode surface, which has led to many schemes for pretreatment and conversion. Chemical decomposition of polymers into monomers is a technological goal for upcycling plastics in which techniques such as hydrolysis, alcoholysis and ammonolysis have been widely studied, while hydrolysis can be notably carried out under relatively mild conditions [19]. Monomers obtained by hydrolysis can be further electrochemically upgraded into value-added chemicals. Taking polyethylene terephthalate (PET) as an example, although hydrolysis under acidic conditions can obtain high yields of terephthalic acid (TPA) [20], the use of a large amounts of acid increases the cost and complexity of the hydrolysis process and negatively affects the purity of the ethylene glycol. In contrast, hydrolysis of PET under environmentally-friendly neutral conditions causes all mechanical impurities present in the polymer to remain in TPA, thereby affecting the purity of TPA. Therefore, as an effective alternative, hydrolysis of PET under alkaline conditions has been widely studied [19]. Other waste polyester plastics (such as polylactic acid, polybutylene terephthalate, poly(butylene adipate-co-terephthalate), and polybutylene succinate) have similar upgrading attributes to PET. Upgrading methods of these depolymerization monomers via electrocatalysis are analyzed in this review. Considering that the electrochemical reaction during the actual process involves two half-reactions, namely the anodic oxidation reaction and the cathodic reduction reaction [16], electrocatalytic upgrading of plastics mainly relies on anodic oxidation reactions, while the most common coupling reaction at the cathode is hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) to obtain green hydrogen. Slow kinetics of HER require a high overpotential to achieve a significant current density, so other electrochemical reduction reactions such as carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR), and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) are being considered to replace HER for reducing reaction energy consumption and obtaining value-added products or energy [21,22]. In view of the possible cathode reduction reactions, it is necessary to analyze electrolytic treatment schemes for polyester waste plastics for the purpose of identifying efficient and energy-saving systems [5,23]. In the past three years, there has been much progress in electrocatalytic methods for conversion of waste plastic monomers. Reviews on waste plastics have mainly focused on the degradation or recycling of a wide range of plastic wastes with electrocatalytic methods [24–26]. This review distinguishes itself from previously published reviews in that it focuses on electrocatalytic upgrading of polyester waste plastic monomers in detail while considering co-generated products of reduction reactions (Fig. 1 ). Firstly, the electrochemical system of waste plastic monomers recycling is introduced, including the pretreatment of waste plastic, the evaluation index during the electrochemical reaction process, and subsequent product recovery techniques. Secondly, research progress in electrocatalyst development is summarized based on the type of depolymerization monomers, target products and coupling reactions. Electrochemical reaction mechanisms are analyzed considering the small molecular structures obtained through pretreatment processes. Finally, ideas on the current research achievements are presented and prospects for further development are discussed with the aim to bring applications into industrial settings. 2 Processes for upgrading monomers derived from waste plastics Electrochemical upcycling of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics involves conversion of materials to products under relatively mild reaction conditions. A typical process for plastic upgrading pretreats the polymer by hydrolysis that is followed by electrocatalytic oxidation to selectively form one or more products that are then recovered by conventional separation techniques such as membrane filtration or distillation. This section provides an overview of factors that affect electrochemical upgrading of waste plastic monomers, including pretreatment of the polymer, evaluation of electrochemical reaction process, reaction metrics and the recovery of products. 2.1 Pretreatment Pretreatment of solid substrates is necessary to obtain a liquid electrolyte suitable for electrocatalytic treatment. Because ester bonds between the monomers of polyester plastics (such as polyethylene terephthalate and polybutylene terephthalate) are easily attacked and broken, rather than the C–C main chains in polyolefins that have strong rigidity, polyester plastics are hydrolyzed into corresponding monomers under acidic, alkaline, or neutral conditions [27,28]. In an alkaline environment, the presence of OH− can be used as a raw material for the oxidation reaction and also in the formation of reactive oxygen species (*OH) [29]. When transition metals are employed in the electrochemical step as electrocatalysts, they exhibit high activity in alkaline environments [30]. Consequently, alkaline hydrolysis finds wide application in electrocatalytic conversion of waste plastic monomers. In the experimental process, commercially available plastic bottles are typically sliced or crushed and directly hydrolyzed in alkaline media to obtain the corresponding monomers [31–33]. However, at ambient temperatures and pressures, hydrolysis is generally inefficient and the reaction is incomplete, such that hydrothermal and solvothermal methods are employed to accelerate the depolymerization of plastics [34,35]. Nevertheless, plastic wastes such as plastic bottles and disposable plastic tableware have different product compositions, making it difficult to determine precise hydrolysis conditions a priori. Furthermore, there are no uniform hydrolysis conditions for the same polyester waste plastic at present and researchers usually choose conditions based on practical results as shown in Table 1 . Therefore, it is necessary to determine the relationship between the mass of the plastic substrate and the concentration of the hydrolysis solution for the pretreatment process. The use of a pretreatment recipe enables quantification of the generated monomers and allows conditions to be chosen for subsequent electrocatalytic treatment. 2.2 Evaluation metrics Fig. 2 is a schematic diagram of the main evaluation metrics used to assess catalytic electrodes for upgrading waste plastic monomers and consists of four cogwheels: (1) electrode activity, (2) electrode stability, (3) reaction kinetics, and (4) energy efficiency. The bases of these cogwheels are conversion, selectivity, yield, productivity, Faraday efficiency, and reusability. 2.2.1 Electrode activity In the laboratory, three-electrode systems are commonly employed in an H-type electrolytic cell for assessing electrode activity. Following the completion of electrocatalyst preparation, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) are used to examine the current density of hydrolysis monomers (e.g. ethylene glycol, and lactic acid) in the electrolyte, thereby providing information on electrode activity. To obtain the target product, it is necessary to select the dominant potential of the product based on LSV curves and to further optimize electrode design. Long-term electrolysis tests are usually conducted with chronoamperometry (CA) or chronopotentiometry (CP), and qualitative or quantitative analyses are performed on post-reaction electrolytes. Product analyses are mainly obtained through nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with the performance of the catalytic electrode being assessed by examining conversion, selectivity, yield, productivity and Faraday efficiency (FE) [29,36,37]. Experimental uncertainties of the data are typically estimated by carbon balance [38]. 2.2.2 Reaction kinetics The Tafel slope is generally used to estimate reaction rate and to obtain insight into the mechanism of electrolysis. Under certain conditions, by analyzing the logarithm of current versus applied potential, the information on the number of proton and electron transfers that occur prior to the rate-determining step can be obtained, which provides key features of the mechanism, thereby allowing one to optimize the catalyst and system to reduce energy barriers and alter selectivity. A low Tafel slope value indicates an active catalyst, because it requires less overpotential to achieve high current density [39,40]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) can be used to analyze the electron transfer that occurs at the electrode-electrolyte interface during an electrochemical reaction. According to the EIS theory, the performance of a catalyst is influenced by several factors related to the electrochemical reaction: (i) ohmic resistance (ion or electron transfer), (ii) double-layer capacitance (kinetic effect), and (iii) charge transfer resistance or polarization resistance (mass transfer effect) [41]. 2.2.3 Electrode stability The stability of an electrode is a crucial factor for ensuring long-term sustainable conversion of waste plastic monomers via electrocatalytic upgrading. Analyses such as CV, CP, and CA can be employed to investigate the stability of a catalyst. Currently, stability tests at the laboratory stage are usually conducted using a three-electrode system in single/double electrolytic cells in which the process is in a relatively static state and the electrolyte is not refreshed. However, the concentration of the reactant monomers in such a static electrolysis cell is limited. After a long period of electrolysis experiments, reactant monomers are gradually converted, which leads to current density curves obtained by CA that gradually decrease, while the CP has an increase in the electrode potential, as shown in Fig. 3 (a and b) [42]. To achieve a longer electrolysis time periods, excessive reaction substrates may be added into the reaction system, whereas the substrate concentration will have a certain impact on the electrolysis, which in turn affects the stability of the catalyst. Therefore, the defects of this method can be improved by periodically refreshing the electrolyte, and the stability test can be achieved for periods of extended long time (Fig. 3c) [43]. However, both aforementioned electrolysis processes are more suitable for operation in the laboratory, so by constructing a dual-electrode membrane electrode assembly (MEA) flow cell and a control system for reaction concentration and flow rate within a certain range, it is more convenient for testing long-term stability as well as confirming stable production by the electrocatalyst (Fig. 3d) [44]. 2.2.4 Energy consumption and energy efficiency Energy consumption and energy efficiency are commonly used metrics to measure the level of energy saving in a system. Many studies focus on the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) as the cathodic pairing reaction, so the energy consumption (W, kWh m−3) is calculated using the hydrogen volume as a reference value [45,46], as displayed in Eq. (1). (1) W = n × F × U × 1000 3600 × V m where n is the number of electrons transferred by each product molecule, F is the Faraday constant, U is the applied voltage, and V m is the molar volume of the gas at ambient temperature and pressure. However, in the full-cell electrolysis process and to improve the energy efficiency, cathodic reactions such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), and nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR) are used as pairing reactions. Therefore, the related specific energy consumptions (kWh g−1) is calculated based on the following Eq. (2) [47]. (2) W = n × F × U × 1000 3600 × F E × M p r o d u c t where n is the number of transferred electrons per mole product, F is the Faraday constant, U is the applied voltage, FE is the Faraday efficiency, and M product is the molar mass of the product. Energy efficiency (EE) is the ratio of the energy required for product generation to the input energy of the entire integrated system. EE is proportional to the Faraday efficiency (FE) and the ratio of the thermodynamic cell voltage to the working cell voltage. Therefore, high values of EE require a reaction system to have high selectivity (high Faraday efficiency) and low power input (low cell voltage). EE can be calculated according to the following Eqs. (3) and (4) [48,49]. For the anode: (3) E E a n o d e = E 0 E f u l l - c e l l a p p l i e d × FE = E m o n o m e r × E H E R E f u l l - c e l l a p p l i e d × F E p r o d u c t where E monomer is the standard electrode potential of the depolymerization monomer oxidation reaction, E HER is the thermodynamic potential of H2O electroreduction to produce hydrogen, FEproduct is the Faraday efficiency of the depolymerization monomer electrocatalysis to produce the target product, and E full-cell applied is the applied full cell voltage. For the cathode: (4) E E c a t h o d e = E 0 - E f u l l - c e l l a p p l i e d × FE = E O E R × E r e d u c t i o n - E f u l l - c e l l a p p l i e d × F E p r o d u c t where E OER is the standard potential of the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (i.e., 1.23 V), E reduction is the thermodynamic potential of the cathodic coupling reaction, FEproduct is the Faraday efficiency of the electrocatalytic reduction reaction to generate the target product, and E full-cell applied is the applied full cell voltage. 2.3 Techno-economic analysis Techno-economic analysis (TEA) can be used to evaluate the feasibility of a plastic waste conversion process, to target economically promising products and to identify performance metrics that should be achieved for economic viability [50]. When evaluating economic efficiency, several key indicators should be considered, including reactants supply cost, electrolysis system cost, and projected profits. Each of these key indicators is influenced by a number of factors. Factors that affect the cost of the electrolysis system include the type of electrolyzer, the electrocatalyst, the membrane, the amount of electricity used, production rate, and product separation [51]. To ensure the economic feasibility of commercialization and industrialization of an electrocatalytic upgrading process, TEA of the anode-cathode integrated system is used. 2.4 Product separation and recovery Product separation and recovery is important for evaluating the feasibility of upgrading and recycling of electrocatalytic waste plastic monomers. Upgrading of polyester plastics yields products that are primarily composed of monomers with double carboxyl groups (e.g. terephthalic acid) and monomers with alcohol hydroxyl groups (e.g. ethylene glycol and 1,4-butanediol). During the process of electrocatalytic upgrading, the monomer with a double carboxyl group structure does not participate in the electron transfer process, while the monomer with alcohol hydroxyl groups is prone to nucleophilic dehydrogenation reaction under electrolysis. Hence, the products to be separated and recovered include the monomer with double carboxyl groups and the oxidation products of the monomer with alcohol hydroxyl groups (e.g. formic acid, glycolic acid, and succinic acid). Among them, terephthalic acid is slightly soluble in water at room temperature (ca. 0.0015 g/100 g) and insoluble in acidic aqueous solutions [52]. By adding mineral acids such as H2SO4, solution pH of the electrolyte can be adjusted to a value between 3 and 4, making it possible to crystallize and separate terephthalic acid from the electrolyte. In the process of electrocatalytic upgrading, ethylene glycol undergoes oxidation to form formic acid, which can be used as a pH regulator to precipitate terephthalic acid, and can also serve as a feedstock for the production of value-added potassium diformate (KDF), which is a product obtained through an acid-base reaction between formic acid and KOH under certain conditions. Glycolic acid can be obtained through desalination. Liquid-liquid extraction, distillation, crystallization, and electrodialysis can be used to refine succinic acid depending on specific conditions. Considering the demand for high-purity products, for any given electrolysis process, it is necessary to develop suitable post-processing methods or protocols [53]. 3 Electrochemical conversion of monomers After preliminary assessment of the electrochemical upgrading recycling process for waste plastic monomers, actual production of value-added products has to consider the types of depolymerization monomers, electrochemical reaction pathways, mechanisms, and the selection of electrocatalysts. 3.1 Ethylene glycol (EG) Polyethylene terephthalate (PET), which is a widely used polyester-type polymer, is one of the most commonly employed plastic materials in electrocatalytic upgrading studies. Alkaline hydrolysis enables complete conversion of PET into terephthalic acid (TPA) and ethylene glycol monomers. TPA can be separated and recovered by adjusting the pH value of the solution (<3), while EG due to its high boiling point (195 °C) requires considerable amount of energy for separation by distillation. Therefore, EG is regarded as a research target. At present, there are two primary targets of EG electrocatalysis: (i) direct use as a fuel for EG fuel cells (C2H6O2 + 5/2O2 → 2CO2 + 3H2O) and (ii) conversion to easily separated products, for example, glycolic acid (GA), formic acid (FA), or carbonates in a sequence known as EG oxidation reaction (EGOR) [54–56]. In EG electrocatalysis, it is necessary to design electrodes according to desired reaction paths that can be considered to be either total oxidation or partial oxidation. 3.1.1 Mechanism of ethylene glycol catalytic oxidation In the EGOR process, there are two main conversion pathways: (1) formation of a C1 product formic acid, through C–C cleavage or (2) formation of a C2 product glycolic acid through C–C preservation (Fig. 4 ). The oxidation of EG initially forms glycolaldehyde, which is further oxidized to glyoxal or glycolic acid. Subsequently, glyoxal undergoes C–C bond cleavage to generate formic acid, with a small amount of glycolic acid also undergoing C–C bond cleavage to generate formic acid and carbonates [57]. Compared with formic acid, glycolic acid as a monomer for biodegradable plastics has higher economic value. When glycolic acid is the target product, it is important to prevent the cleavage of C–C bonds and avoid overoxidation, while selectively oxidizing one of the hydroxymethyl groups in EG, which requires a specific design for the catalyst. In addition, the catalyst should have the ability to adsorb and oxidize CO to inhibit active site poisoning. Dissociative adsorption is responsible for C–C bond cleavage, which requires adjacent metal active sites to adsorb C2 carbon atoms. Therefore, electrocatalytic active sites with strong carbon adsorption ability should not be too dense to reduce the possibility of C–C bond cleavage due to carbon atom dissociation adsorption [44,58]. For example, Liu et al. [59] demonstrated through experiments that the introduction of a small amount of Sn into Pt facilitated the cleavage of C–C bonds and promoted the oxidative removal of *CO intermediates. Wang et al. [60] showed that the stronger the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for the reaction intermediate glyoxal, the fewer side reactions related to the formation of GA, which could effectively promote the cleavage of C–C bonds. On the contrary, Wang et al. [61] introduced Cu to form a Pd-Cu binary alloy to adjust the electronic structure of Pd, so that the d-band center of Pd was reduced, which was beneficial to the desorption of GA and prevented further cleavage of the C–C bond. 3.1.2 Ethylene glycol oxidation reaction coupled with hydrogen evolution reaction Hydrogen has received extensive attention as a clean and renewable resource due to its high energy density, non-toxic nature, and near-zero greenhouse gas emissions. Among the hydrogen production technologies, electrochemical water splitting is considered to be an economical and environmentally-friendly approach. Water electrolysis involves a two-step two-electron hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and a proton-coupled four-step four-electron oxygen evolution reaction (OER), both of which are kinetically slow [62,63]. Simultaneously, in the electrolytic cell, the oxygen produced at the anode has a lower value, and it crosses and mixes with the gas H2 produced at the cathode, which can lead to dangerous explosion hazards [54,64]. Therefore, it is necessary to replace OER with a more thermodynamically favorable organic oxidation reaction to allow high-value products form at the anode [65]. EG, which is as one of the depolymerization monomers of PET, with its lower overpotential and higher solubility in water at room temperature has favorable thermodynamic properties for OER. EG can be converted into FA or GA through electrochemical catalysis thereby having potential economic benefits. Therefore, some researchers have proposed coupling the electrooxidation of EG with anode hydrogen production to replace traditional water oxidation [66–68]. In this regard, designing highly efficient electrocatalysts to obtain target products is the main challenge in research. 3.1.2.1 C1 product As the main C1 product after electrochemical upgrading of PET, FA not only solves the problem of separating EG after PET water degradation, but also improves the subsequent revenue of the product. In the electrochemical conversion of EG to FA, electrocatalysts have been developed and applied (Table 2 ) for FA production coupled with cathodic hydrogen production. Noble metal-based catalysts exhibit exceptional performance in alkaline media for small molecule alcohol oxidation and serve as efficient electrocatalysts. Song et al. [57] used a corrosion strategy to synthesize a series of single-atom electrocatalysts based on noble metals (Entry 1, Table 2), enabling the electrochemical upgrading cycle of PET to produce value-added potassium diformate (KDF, via FA) and TPA, while also producing H2. The electrochemical test results showed that single-atom Pt1/Ni(OH)2-3 electrocatalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance affording over 90% selectivity towards FA. The catalytic performance of Pt1/Ni(OH)2-3 was attributed to the lower Gibbs energy of the glycolaldehyde intermediate, while the Gibbs energy of the intermediate was increased in the presence of nanoparticles Pt/NF and Pt/Ni(OH)2/NF. Techno-economic analysis (TEA) indicated that operating the electrochemical PET upgrading recycling process with Pt1/Ni(OH)2-3 catalyst would bring revenues as high as 700 $ ton−1 PET, based on the high current density and high FE. Unfortunately, precious metal-based electrocatalysts have limited application in EG electrocatalytic processes due to cost and are prone to deactivation due to intermediate poisoning. Therefore, to overcome these issues, bimetallic or multimetallic materials based on precious metals are being actively studied [69]. Zhang et al. [70] designed and constructed an organic ligand-modified PdNi bimetallic olefin (PdNiO-BMs) catalyst through a one-pot method (Entry 2, Table 2). The introduction of a small amount of Ni element changed the electronic structure of Pd, resulting in improved activity and stability of the catalyst. By using curled porous surface structures and the modification of inorganic-organic hybrid interface, PdNiO-BMs could effectively produce FA through the electrocatalytic reforming of EG extracted from PET. Density functional theory calculations confirmed that the addition of Ni element and n-octanoic acid enhanced the conductivity, thereby improving the adsorption of reactants and enhancing the catalytic performance. Zhang et al. [71] loaded PdFe bimetallic nanoparticles on nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (PdFe/N-CNT) for electrochemical upgrading of anode PET waste while generating H2 at the cathode (Entry 3, Table 2). Due to the unique structural characteristics of N-doped carbon nanotubes and the downward shift of the d-band center caused by Fe-doped Pd, the PdFe/N-CNTs bifunctional catalyst exhibited good electrocatalytic performance for both EGOR and HER in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte. Additionally, the preliminary TEA resulted in a net income of approximately $411.9 per ton of PET waste converted. To reduce costs, design of transition metal-based electrocatalysts is one viable approach. Among the possible transition metals, Ni-based electrodes have been extensively studied due to their high catalytic activity towards EGOR. Liu et al. [72] employed an acid etching method to prepare a Ni foam catalyst rich in Ni(OH)2 for selective electrocatalytic reforming of PET-derived EG to produce FA and H2 fuel. The results demonstrated that Ni(OH)2/NF had high Faraday efficiency and FA selectivity at moderate current densities and potentials (Entry 5, Table 2). Furthermore, the combination of in-situ electrochemical Raman spectroscopy, in-situ electrochemical Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra analyses showed that a substantial amount of NiOOH species generated in-situ during PET electro-reforming process reacted with EG as chemical oxidant and led to highly efficient EGOR activity. Kang et al. [73] used electrochemical deposition method to construct Cu onto Ni foam (NiCu/NF) for upgrading and recycling of EG and PET plastics (Fig. 5 a) (Entry 6, Table 2). Through electrochemical testing and product analysis (Fig. 5b and c), the addition of Cu was found to enhance the selectivity of the catalyst as well as increase the potential difference (ΔE) between EGOR and OER. Moreover, the NiCu60s/NF showed higher FE (95.8%) and yield (0.70 mmol cm−2 h−1) for FA compared with pristine NF (64.8% and 0.17 mmol cm−2 h−1). By combining ex-situ and in-situ characterization, changes of Ni and Cu during reconstruction and after EGOR and OER could be inferred (Fig. 5d), indicating that NiOOH and CuOOH/Cu(OH)2 were the key active species. After EGOR and OER, the active species were further converted into corresponding low-oxidized metallic compounds. Additionally, density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the Gibbs energy barrier (ΔG) for the rate-determining step of EGOR on NiCu/NF was lower at 0.51 eV compared with that on pristine Ni foam at 1.41 eV (Fig. 5e). Presence of Cu promoted the cleavage of the C–C bond, thereby reducing the ΔG of *COOHCH2OH to *CH2OH + HCOOH step. The proposed mechanism involved an indirect oxidation pathway (Fig. 5f), where Ni(OH)2 is oxidized to NiOOH, and NiOOH serves as a chemical oxidant to extract α-hydrogen atoms from the adsorbed alcohol, which is the rate-determining step of the electrochemical oxidation process. In this step, NiOOH is converted back to Ni(OH)2. The main role of the bias voltage is to regenerate NiOOH as oxidant. Finally, the electrocatalytic upgrading and recycling of commercial PET plastic powder and commercial PET plastic bottle waste hydrolysate could be carried out using NiCu/NF catalyst, which could selectively convert PET-derived EG into FA as the only conversion product, which has high merit in reducing the downstream costs associated with product separation. It can be observed that the Ni-based electrocatalysts mentioned above mainly convert Ni(OH)2 into NiOOH, where NiOOH serves as the predominant active material. In addition to the outstanding performance of NiOOH catalyst in EGOR, common transition metal oxides (such as single metal oxides and spinel metal oxides) have also gained attention for the EGOR process. Wang et al. [55] synthesized CuO nanowires grown on copper foils and used Cu-based nanowire catalysts for electrochemical upgrading and recycling of PET hydrolysates through electrocatalytic oxidation (Entry 7, Table 2). By comparing the electrocatalytic performance of Cu(OH)2 nanowires and CuO nanowires, it was observed that metal oxides exhibit high catalytic activity. DFT calculations revealed that the C–C bond cleavage of glyoxal intermediate on the surface of CuO nanowires is the rate-determining step in the EGOR process, so the oxidation pathway of EG on CuO can selectively break the C–C bond to generate FA. Furthermore, the formation of glyoxal intermediate is the optimal reaction pathway to produce FA. Spinel oxides have attracted attention in electrocatalysis due to their favorable properties such as high plasticity, low cost, easy synthesis, and diverse structures/compositions. Moreover, due to their electronic structure, multiple compositions, and valence states, spinel oxides tend to have high catalytic activity. Among the spinel oxides and due to the redox activity of Co element, application of Co-based spinel in electrocatalysis has been widely studied. Zhao et al. [74] used waste lithium-ion batteries as raw materials to synthesize Co3O4 material (Entry 8, Table 2), which could convert PET bottles into high-purity FA and TPA products at ambient temperature. The study showed that the electrocatalytic performance that was superior for OER was mainly due to rapid charge transfer kinetics and EG molecule adsorption in the Helmholtz layer. Liu et al. [75] reported an electrocatalyst comprising a nanowire array of CuCo2O4 on Ni foam for selective oxidation upgrading of polyester plastics (Entry 9, Table 2). The CuCo2O4 catalyst exhibited remarkable activity in converting polyester plastics (PET, PBT, and PLA). Particularly, PET-derived EG could be selectively electrooxidized to FA even at current densities up to 100 mA cm−2 and with a high Faraday efficiency (93%) and selectivity (86%) (Entry 9, Table 2). To further enhance the catalytic performance of a catalyst, element doping is considered as a useful approach that can modify both the crystal structure and interface properties, thereby improving both catalytic activity and stability. Mao et al. [35] synthesized rod-like fibers made up of Mn0.1Ni0.9Co2O4− δ and employed them as electrocatalysts to convert PET microplastics into KDF, TPA, and K2SO4. In the electrochemical system, HER occurred simultaneously at the cathode to produce H2. The electrochemical system exhibited high Faraday efficiency (>95%) and good FA productivity at 1.42 V vs. RHE (Entry 10, Table 2). Li et al. [76] prepared a series of cobalt spinel oxides with transition metals (M) as M0.5Ce0.5Co2O4 on Ni foam as electrocatalysts for selective oxidation of PET to FA and TPA in which the release of H2 occurred at the cathode. Among the electrocatalysts, Ni0.5Ce0.5Co2O4 demonstrated good performance with higher oxidation activity towards PET hydrolysate than water (potential difference was about 200 mV). For the Ni0.5Ce0.5Co2O4 catalyst, selectivity of FA reached 91.8%, while Faraday efficiency was 95% (Entry 11, Table 2) that could be explained as follows. On the one hand, the introduction of Ce with its large atomic radius into the Co3O4 lattice caused the lattice to expand, resulting in the formation of more oxygen vacancies. With additional oxygen vacancies, Ni0.5Ce0.5Co2O4 had a stronger binding force with the OHad intermediate, which was beneficial for the capture of OH−, thus promoting the oxidation of EG. On the other hand, the introduction of Ni enhanced the dynamic adsorption process of EG, while inhibiting the formation of *O intermediate at the catalyst interface, thereby suppressing the activity of the side reaction OER. In the design process of the aforementioned reaction system, only the electrocatalyst for the anode was targeted, while HER on the cathode was Pt as electrocatalyst. Therefore, the construction of bifunctional electrocatalysts offers advantages in terms of reducing overall costs and simplifying the complexity of the electrolytic cell. To ensure that bifunctional electrocatalysts have good EGOR and HER activity, catalytic materials such as transition metal sulfides [77], phosphides [78], or nitrides [79] can be employed. Zhou et al. [43] have developed a nickel-modified cobalt phosphide (CoNi0.25P) bifunctional electrocatalyst that upgraded PET waste into KDF and TPA commercial chemicals in KOH electrolyte and paired it with H2 production (Entry 14, Table 2). The prepared samples were evaluated for their performance for HER (Fig. 6 a), OER (Fig. 6b), and EGOR (Fig. 6c) under alkaline conditions (1 M KOH). As depicted in Fig. 6(a), CoNi0.25P/NF exhibited better HER performance over other materials due to a decrease of charge transfer resistance and an increase in electrochemically active surface area. The catalytic oxidation performance of CoNi x P/NF and Ni2P/NF electrocatalysts was further evaluated under 1 M KOH and 0.3 M EG conditions. In the absence of EG, all electrocatalysts exhibited comparable OER activity with an onset potential around 1.51 V vs. RHE (Fig. 6b). However, upon introduction of 0.3 M EG into the electrolyte, the onset potential of all electrocatalysts shifted to lower potentials (1.22 to 1.33 V vs. RHE) (Fig. 6c), indicating that the oxidation of EG is thermodynamically more favorable than OER. Combined with HER performance, a zero-gap membrane electrode assembly (MEA) flow reactor was designed that used CoNi0.25P/NF as both cathode and anode catalysts for converting EG into FA and generating H2 (Fig. 6d). The LSV polarization curves of traditional water splitting (HER//OER) and EG electrolysis (HER//EGOR) were obtained on this device (Fig. 6e) and demonstrated that the cell voltage was reduced by approximately 189 mV at the same current density in the presence of EG in the electrolyte, thereby improving the cathode energy efficiency. In addition, it was found that the in-situ evolution of CoNi0.25P catalyst into low-crystalline metal oxide (hydroxide) as the active state during the EG oxidation process might account for the performance benefits. Wang et al. [42] also obtained similar conclusions. Based on ordered macroporous ZIF-67 single crystals, they developed a bifunctional electrocatalyst of Ni atom-modified CoP (OMS-Ni1-CoP) (Entry 16, Table 2), which possessed embedded mesopores and finely ordered macroporous upper structure (Fig. 6f). The catalyst exhibited numerous ordered macropores and integrated mesopores, resulting in a large surface area that promoted mass transfer. By investigating the electrocatalytic HER (Fig. 6g) and EGOR (Fig. 6h) performance of OMS-Ni1-CoP in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, it was observed that OMS-Ni1-CoP could achieve a HER overpotential of 119 mV at a current density of −10 mA cm−2 and an EGOR overpotential of 1.30 V at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The structure and morphology of OMS-Ni1-CoP were characterized after the EGOR reaction and showed that the phosphide underwent electrochemical reconstruction before the anodic catalytic oxidation reaction to form a metal hydroxyl oxide (Ni-CoOOH) as the actual active substance, which was thermodynamically more favorable for EGOR. Finally, the two half-reactions were integrated into a complete cell structure for H2 and value-added FA production (Fig. 6i). The LSV results are shown in Fig. 6(j), where the current density of OMS-Ni1-CoP//OMS-Ni1-CoP at 1.52 V could reach 10 mA cm−2, which was 160 mV lower than that of the HER/OER system, indicating the energy-saving advantage of replacing OER with EGOR. Furthermore, the OMS-Ni1-CoP//OMS-Ni1-CoP exhibited a higher activity than the commercial Pt/C//RuO2 in the HER//EGOR pair-electrolysis, showing great potential for cost savings and energy-efficient H2 production. Ma et al. [80] adopted a transition metal nitride-induced growth strategy to design a Ni3N/W5N4 high-efficiency bifunctional electrode featuring Janus nanostructure and barrier-free heterogeneous interface (Entry 19, Table 2). The Ni3N/W5N4 Janus nanostructure demonstrated high HER and EGOR activities attributed to synergistic effects of the multilayer sponge structure and heterogeneous interface. Under a potential of 1.60 V vs. RHE, the current density reached 120 mA cm−2, and the FE of FA was as high as 85 % (Entry 19, Table 2). Characterization of the catalyst post-EGOR revealed certain reconstruction during the oxidation process, leading to changes in both morphology and crystal structure of Ni3N and W5N4. It could be further inferred that the selective formation of FA by EGOR was due to MOOH acting as the true active site, which caused the C–C bond of the glyoxal intermediate to cleave and form FA. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are appealing as electrocatalysis because of their high porosity, rich catalytic molecular units, ultrathin two-dimensional morphology, and highly accessible active sites. Guo et al. [81] synthesized Te-doped Co-MOF nanomaterials (TbCo-MOF/NF) on nickel foam as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for simultaneously promoting hydrogen evolution reaction and PET hydrolysate oxidation (Entry 23, Table 2). During the electrochemical process, TbCo-MOF nanoflakes generated Tb-CoOOH at the anode and Tb-Co(OH)2 at the cathode, serving as the true active substances for catalyzing the oxidation reaction of PET hydrolysate and HER. The study found that the addition of trace Tb could effectively adjust the interface electronic structure between Tb and Co, thereby optimizing the adsorption and activation of reactants and ultimately improving the electrochemical performance of the catalyst. The catalytic performance of TbCo-MOF/NF was evaluated in 1 M KOH electrolyte containing 0.5 M EG at a current density of 100 mA cm−2. The EGOR potential of TbCo-MOF/NF was determined to be 1.32 V, which is 241 mV lower than the OER potential. In the two-electrode co-electrolysis system, TbCo-MOF/NF achieved a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.55 V, with a 160 mV reduction in voltage compared with complete hydrolysis. This study provides a valuable reference for developing high-value bifunctional electrocatalysts for the electrocatalytic upgrading of PET waste plastic. 3.1.2.2 C2 product Conversion of EG into C1 products (FA) via electrocatalysis may result in energy wastage, so it can be more cost-effective to target selective production of high-value C2 products (GA). However, operating at a high current density (>300 mA cm−2) during industrial production can lead to the cleavage of C–C bonds and other conditions, resulting in low selectivity and FE of C2 products. Therefore, it is possible to design electrocatalysts that inhibit the cleavage of C–C bonds, enabling EG to be directedly converted into GA. Table 3 summarizes electrocatalysts for EGOR production of GA coupled with cathode HER. Noble metal-based catalysts, such as Au, Pt, and Pd, exhibit the ability to oxidize EG at moderate potentials while avoiding excessive oxidative cleavage of C–C bonds, which enables the production of GA products with high selectivity [82]. In typical reactions on noble metal catalysts, active oxygen species are produced by electro-oxidation of H2O or OH− at a low potential on the noble metal surface in the form of adsorbed hydroxyl groups (*OH). The *OH can effectively catalyze EG dehydrogenation at a moderate potentials (<1.0 V vs. RHE) to generate C2 products that maintain the C–C bond. However, noble metal catalysts suffer from limited durability due to their high sensitivity to carbonyl intermediates leading to rapid loss of activity within a few hours [83]. Therefore, one possible strategy is to improve the activity and durability of the catalyst by precisely controlling the structure and composition as well as designing electronic structure and adsorption sites of the catalyst. Chen et al. [84] used a non-metal alloying strategy to prepare a Pd-boron aerogel (PdB), in which B atoms were induced to regulate the electronic structure and surface hydrophilicity (Entry 2, Table 3). In situ experiments and DFT calculations revealed the contribution of B insertion into the Pd lattice that gave efficient transformation of EG to GA. Importantly, B doping enhanced the surface hydrophilicity and regulated the electronic structure, reducing the adsorption of *CO intermediates and enhancing the affinity of hydroxyl species and accelerating the formation of oxidative *OHad species, thus coordinately avoiding over-oxidation and promoting the synthesis of GA. Due to the insertion of B, the intrinsic activity of PdB was enhanced (6.71 A mgPd −1), which almost nine times that of commercial Pd/C. Furthermore, PdB exhibited an outstanding GA Faraday efficiency of 93.8% at 0.7 V vs. RHE and performed well in long-term stability tests (Entry 2, Table 3). Wang et al. [85] synthesized non-separated Pd1Ag1 alloy nanoparticles for the electrochemical conversion of waste PET to GA and obtained selectivities as high as 97% and long-term stability of more than 500 h (50–60 mA mgPd −1) (Entry 3, Table 3). The results of electrochemical tests and in-situ analyses demonstrated that Ag atoms reduced the adsorption energy of GA on Pd sites, thereby preventing excessive oxidation to achieve good GA selectivity. Moreover, due to the high affinity of Ag atom sites with water, a large amount of *OH active species were induced, which promoted the rapid oxidation of carbonyl compounds at Pd active sites, thereby alleviating catalyst poisoning and improving the stability of the catalyst. Li et al. [86] synthesized boron (B) and phosphorus (P) co-doped PdRh nanosheets (PdRhBP) catalyst by a two-step method, aiming to facilitate the conversion of PET plastic hydrolysate EG into GA (Entry 4, Table 3). The two-dimensional structure of PdRhBP nanosheets enabled exposure of more active sites, thereby enhancing electron/mass transfer kinetics. Namely, combination of B and P regulated the electronic state of Pd, which made PdRhBP nanosheets have high EGOR performance. The mass activity of PdRhBP nanosheets was 1.69 A mg−1, three times that of Pd black (0.57 A mg−1). Incorporation of noble metals and oxygen-affinitive non-noble metal catalysts to construct composite catalysts is another approach to solving issues related to noble metals such as deactivation. Liu et al. [44] employed a hydrothermal method to prepare a Pd-Ni(OH)2/Ni foam catalyst (Pd-Ni(OH)2/NF) for EGOR synthesis of GA (Fig. 7 a) (Entry 5, Table 3). Fig. 7(b) shows the LSV of Pd-Ni(OH)2/NF in 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution with or without 1.0 M EG. Upon addition of 1.0 M EG, the current density increased dramatically and only 0.69 V vs. RHE was required to provide a current density of 100 mA cm−2. Furthermore, within a wide potential range (0.7 to 1.2 V vs. RHE), the FE of GA reached more than 90% (Fig. 7c). Since the adsorption/activation of OH− plays a key role in EGOR, the adsorption/activation of OH− species was studied in detail by CV (Fig. 7d), which revealed that the introduction of oxygen-affinitive Ni species could effectively facilitate the oxidation of OH− on the Pd surface to form *OH adsorbed species at a relatively low potential, and *OH adsorbed species were the main active species involved in EGOR. DFT calculations showed the origin of GA selectivity to be the formation of *OH active species as the rate-determining step. The free energy change for the rate-determining step on Pd-Ni(OH)2 was lower than that on pure Pd structure (0.68 to 0.51 eV) (Fig. 7e). According to a preliminary TEA for the Pd-Ni(OH)2/NF catalyst, the PET electrochemical conversion strategy was projected to give a total revenue of up to $348.7 per ton of PET. Yan et al. [87] achieved good selectivity (>91%) for EGOR to product GA at moderate potential and high current density (up to 326.2 mA cm−2 at 1.15 V vs. RHE), by using nickel hydroxide-supported gold (Au/Ni(OH)2) electrocatalyst (Entry 6, Table 3). To evaluate the catalytic performance under the practical conditions, a custom-made membrane-less flow-stacked electrolytic cell was constructed. An absolute current of about 4.7 A was generated at 1.4 V and the productivity of GA was 471.2 mmol in 12.8 h with a selectivity of 94% and an FE of 96%. Although Pd-based and Au-based catalysts are highly effective for selective oxidation of EG to produce GA, their large operating voltages (>1 V) or high noble metal loading densities (>1 mg cm−2) under industrial settings are considered as the main obstacle to their adoption. The use of low-mass noble metal-loaded engineering catalysts to oxidize EG to GA at marginal voltages will further enhance the economic feasibility of PET plastic waste electro-upgrading and recycling technology. Du et al. [34] compared the costs and benefits of electrochemical treatment of PET waste and conventional chemical oxidation treatment of PET based on the results of TEA and found that electrochemical valorization of PET waste for GA and H2 had higher profitability. Those authors identified a catalyst consisting of Pt nanoparticles anchored on Ni foam (Pt/γNiOOH/NF) for the electrochemical conversion of PET hydrolysis products to GA at the anode and coupled it with the HER at the cathode (Fig. 8 a) (Entry 7, Table 3). The EG oxidation performance of electrodes with different Pt loadings on PET hydrolysates was evaluated by polarization curves (Fig. 8b), and the results showed that the Pt/γ-NiOOH/NF electrode exhibited higher activity when mass loading of Pt was controlled at 0.9 wt%. Furthermore, the Pt/γNiOOH/NF catalyst showed high FE (>85%) and selectivity (>95%) at all applied potentials ranging from 0.45 to 0.65 V (Fig. 8c). For these cases, the HER activity on Pt/γ-NiOOH/NF was measured in alkaline medium to have an overpotential of 86 mV at 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 8d). Further, the Pt/γ-NiOOH/NF was used as the anode and cathode in a MEA closed-loop flow reactor for the electrolytic reforming of PET degradation products (Fig. 8e and f). The EG conversion rate was approximately 59% after 10 h of electrolysis, with an FE of 95% and selectivity of 96% for GA with a carbon balance of 94%. Finally, in the open circuit potential (OCP) measurements (Fig. 8g) combined with DFT calculations (Fig. 8h), results confirmed that the Pt/γ-NiOOH interface had a strong adsorption ability for EG that enabled efficient conversion of EG to GA through synergistic effects between Pt and γ-NiOOH. 3.1.2.3 Other products In addition to the aforementioned products, EGOR electrolytic reforming can also produce carbonates. Shi et al. [88] converted PET into TPA and carbonate using Pd-modified Ni foam (Pd/NF) catalyst. The optimal potential of EG oxidation with Pd/NF-10 was determined by chronoamperometry (Fig. 9 a), where a sharp decrease in the current density was observed at 0.92 V vs. RHE, indicating the formation of carbonaceous intermediates such as CO-type species at high potential, which adversely affected the performance of the Pd/NF catalyst. The lower electrochemical potential (0.7 V vs. RHE, Fig. 9a) showed the possibility of enhancing the stability of the Pd/NF-10 catalyst. Therefore, electrolysis was performed at 0.7 V vs. RHE for 20 h and the products were detected (Fig. 9b), where it was found that as the amount of carbonate increased and the content of EG decreased, glyoxal was also produced during this process. Based on this, the proposed mechanism of C–C bond cleavage in EG oxidation in alkaline condition was proposed (Fig. 9c). It could be found that glyoxal is the main intermediate in the reaction process. Different from the reaction pathway of EG oxidation to FA, glyoxal is oxidized to oxalic acid, and the C–C bond of oxalic acid is broken to obtain carbonate. By examining the stability of Pd/NF-10 for PET electro-reforming through an electrolytic cycle (Fig. 9d), it could be seen that the initial current density remained 97% after five cycles, indicating the high stability of the Pd/NF-10 electrode. Although this work can achieve a complete conversion of PET, the added value of one of the products, carbonate, is still not high enough. 3.1.3 EG electrochemical oxidation coupling with other cathode reduction reactions The initial potential of anode EGOR is lower than that of OER, enabling the coupling of other cathode half-reactions with EGOR to reduce energy consumption and enhance economic benefits. Table 4 provides a summary of reaction studies involving EGOR coupled with cathode half-reactions, such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), and nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR). 3.1.3.1 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) ORR can efficiently convert chemical energy of many kinds of compounds into electricity. However, the kinetics of ORR is sluggish and requires catalysts. Currently, ORR can be divided into two categories based on different electron transfer pathways: (i) a 2e-pathway that reduces O2 to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) that is of great significance for clean and in-situ production of hydrogen peroxide and (ii) a 4e-pathway that reduces O2 to H2O, playing a vital role in the development of next-generation energy devices like fuel cells and metal-air batteries [89–91]. Therefore, it is essential to design the catalyst tailored to meet specific requirements of the reaction process to achieve selective conversion. Qi et al. [92] developed an electrochemical system for the oxidation of EG coupled with ORR (Entry 1, Table 4) aiming to address the challenges of sluggish OER and extraction of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The bimetallic Ni-Mn catalysts and onion carbon (a carbon nanomaterial composed of a core of C60 molecules surrounded by multiple concentric quasi-spherical or polyhedral graphene-like layers) catalysts were divided into anode and cathode, enabling selective conversion of ORR to H2O2 and EGOR to FA with an FE of 93.0% for FA production (Fig. 10 a) and a 97.5% H2O2 generation (Fig. 10b) (Entry 1, Table 4). The catalyst was loaded on the gas diffusion electrode, and the cathode and anode were separated by a commercial ion exchange membrane (Fig. 10c). Remarkably, this ORR//EGOR electrosynthesis system could exhibit stable operation for 36000 s (10 h) at a cell voltage input of 0.7 V, indicating its high potential for practical applications in energy conversion systems (Fig. 10d). Furthermore, H2O2 products were upgraded and recovered through two downstream routes by converting them into sodium perborate and benzoyl peroxide. Finally, the economic potential of the ORR//PET upgraded recycling system was further demonstrated by quantifying the costs and profits of raw materials, equipment, operations, and products. TEA results showed that the electricity cost of the ORR//PET electrosynthesis system was 51.3% lower than that of the HER//PET upgraded recycling configuration and 18.5% lower than that of the ORR//OER configuration (Fig. 10e), highlighting the market competitiveness and economic potential of the ORR//PET electrosynthesis system. Feng et al. [93] utilized a photoelectrochemical strategy to couple the ORR with EGOR of PET hydrolysate. This approach used a porous hollow double-shell Z-scheme Mo2N-Co3O4@Fe2O3/PVDF/NF cathode and Co3O4/NF anode within the cell electrolyte chamber (Entry 2, Table 4). It was observed that EGOR had an auxiliary effect on ORR, leading to at least a threefold increase in the yield of H2O2 produced by ORR compared with water oxidation reaction with ORR. To further reduce the cost of the reaction system, Liu et al. [94] coupled EGOR with HER/ORR for simultaneous hydrogen/electricity generation. They used a Pt-Ni(OH)2/NF electrode in EGOR to produce GA at a low potential (100 mA cm−2 @0.69 V vs. RHE), achieving a high FE (93%) (Entry 3, Table 4). The reaction pathway and mechanism were studied by in-situ analyses that showed synergistic interactions between Pt and Ni(OH)2 and adsorption/desorption of intermediate products on metal sites, thereby ensuring enhanced activity, selectivity, and stability in EGOR. Furthermore, based on the inherent catalytic activity of Pt-based materials for HER and ORR, they coupled EGOR with HER/ORR to establish an electrolysis platform (Fig. 11 a). During daytime operation, solar energy serves as the electric power source driving PET electrical reforming coupling with HER, so as to achieve the simultaneous production of GA and H2. At night-time, a direct alcohol fuel cell (DAFC) system is formed by coupling the PET electro-reforming process with ORR to produce electricity. Furthermore, based on preliminary TEA, the economic feasibility of integrating the EGOR-HER/ORR liquid flow battery system was evaluated (Fig. 11b and c), which shows the possibility of economic profitability. 3.1.3.2 Carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) The electrochemical CO2RR into value-added chemicals and fuels using intermittent renewable electricity is considered to be one of the most promising and environmentally-friendly technologies to simultaneously address environmental issues and energy demands. The multiple proton-coupled electron transfer processes in CO2RR can produce a diverse range of products, among which FA is one of the most valuable products [95,96]. Therefore, combining CO2RR as the cathode half-reaction with the anode EGOR can produce carbonaceous products at both the cathode and anode, which not only provides a synergistic positive effect on carbon neutralization, but also improves economic benefits [97]. Wang et al. [98] used spinel NiCo2O4 as the anode catalyst for electrocatalytic oxidation of PET hydrolysate to produce FA, while tin dioxide (SnO2) nanosheets were chosen as the cathode catalyst for CO2RR to FA (Entry 4, Table 4). By coupling the two half-reactions to produce FA at both the anode and cathode simultaneously, the integrated reaction system could be driven at a cell voltage of 1.55 V. Moreover, the FE of FA at a cell voltage of 1.90 V reached 155%. Finally, a preliminary TEA of this coupling strategy showed that converting PET plastic and CO2 waste into FA could yield a net income of approximately $557 per ton of PET. Ma et al. [99] used PET derivative TPA as feedstock material to prepare cathode and anode electrocatalysts for simultaneous upgrading of PET plastic and CO2 waste into FA (Fig. 12 a). The prepared oxygen-rich Ni(OH)2-Vo and Bi/Bi2O3 heterostructures achieved industrial-scale current density at ultra-low potentials and exhibited high selectivities for FA (86% and 91%, respectively) (Entry 5, Table 4). The chemical process between Ni3+ and EG was studied using in-situ Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 12b and c), which showed that the oxygen vacancies in Ni(OH)2-Vo not only facilitated the conversion of Ni2+ to Ni3+, but also accelerated the subsequent chemical reaction between Ni3+ and EG. A solar flow reactor with real-time monitoring and control functions was further designed (Fig. 12d). With the addition of PET hydrolysate, the current density increased (Fig. 12e), indicating that replacing OER with EGOR at the anode will reduce overall energy consumption. For this system, the overall Faraday efficiency of FA production reached 181% (Fig. 12f). Hao et al. [100] synthesized Ni3Bi2S2 and Bi2S3 as precatalysts through a sulfidation-reconstruction strategy and in-situ reconstructed them into the anode NiOOH/Ni3Bi2S2 and the cathode Bi (1.5S) during the electrolysis process (Entry 7, Table 4). The high electrocatalytic performance (FE > 90%) and stability (>30 h) of the anode NiOOH/Ni3Bi2S2 and the cathode Bi (1.5S) were attributed to the exposure of genuine active sites after reconstruction. The zero-gap membrane electrode assembly electrolyzer with the PET hydrolysis reaction and CO2RR coupled achieved a total FE of 175% for FA co-production. 3.1.3.3 Nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR) Due to the use of fertilizers and fuels in combustion processes, nitrate (NO3 −) contamination occurs through runoff, wastewater, and air pollution. Excessive nitrates pose a threat to the global nitrogen balance, while nitrates can enter the human body through various daily channels and incomplete conversion into nitrite in the body may result in disease [101]. To mitigate the adverse effects of nitrate, methods have been proposed to remove NO3 − from wastewater. Among them, electrochemical NO3RR is considered to be an environmentally-friendly approach with the advantages of mild reaction conditions and high efficiency for nitrate removal. In NO3RR, N2 and NH3 are the main products obtained. Compared with N2, which lacks value-added benefits, NH3 can serve as a valuable source of carbon-free fuel besides being widely used as fertilizer. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop suitable electrocatalysts for selectively producing NH3 through NO3RR [102,103]. To enhance the efficiency of NO3RR, the anode-associated OER (NO3RR//OER) in full cell electrolysis must be considered. However, the anode half-reaction of OER consumes up to 90% of the input energy, while producing low-value O2, which leads to a large increase in energy consumption and production costs of NO3RR. Therefore, replacing OER with other oxidation reactions that are thermodynamically more favorable, particularly waste pollutants, is an emerging strategy to reduce the cell potential and energy input of electrochemical synthesis systems [104,105]. Considering that EG, which is a hydrolysis product of waste plastic PET, exhibits higher thermodynamic advantage for oxidation reaction, incorporating PET reforming into the nitrate wastewater electrolysis process allows for upgrading both wastes into high value-added products such as NH3, potassium diformate, and TPA. This approach not only reduces the overall potential but also enhances economic value. Ren et al. [31] developed Ru-Co-based MOF nanosheets grown on nickel foam (CoRu-MOF/NF) as a bifunctional precatalyst for coupling NO3RR and PET upgrading (Entry 8, Table 4). The CoRu-MOF precatalyst was reconstructed in-situ into Ru-Co(OH)2 and Ru-CoOOH under electrocatalytic action of the cathode and anode, respectively, serving as the actual active catalysts for NO3RR and the oxidation of PET hydrolysates (Fig. 13 a). For NO3RR electrocatalysis under the condition of −0.3 V vs. RHE, high NH3 yields (0.244 mmol h cm−2), FE (94.3%), and selectivity (98.6%) were obtained. Simultaneously, during the anodic EG oxidation process, Ru-CoOOH/NF achieved EG oxidation to FA in PET hydrolysate at 1.33 V vs. RHE with an FE of 96.5%, which demonstrated that the synergism between Ru and Co active sites enhanced the electrocatalytic performance of Ru-Co(OH)2 and Ru-CoOOH for NO3RR and the oxidation of PET hydrolysates. Furthermore, the dual-electrode co-electrolysis system, coupled with NO3RR and PET hydrolysate oxidation, could produce NH3 at the cathode and FA at the anode under low-energy consumption (Fig. 13b–d). To maximize the economic benefits of the product, Ren et al. [106] designed an anode electrocatalyst to oxidize EG derived from PET hydrolysate into GA, thereby improving carbon source utilization, and coupled it with NO3RR to produce NH3. They prepared the low-crystalline CoOOH/CF (LC-CoOOH/CF) by in-situ oxidation of cobalt foam as catalyst for NO3RR. On the other hand, Pd nanothorns grown on nickel foam (Pd NTs/NF) were synthesized by emulsion-assisted electrodeposition as electrocatalysts for anodic reaction (Entry 9, Table 4). The electrochemical test results demonstrated that LC-CoOOH/CF exhibited high catalytic performance for NO3RR, with the NO3 − conversion efficiency approaching 100% and the FE as high as 97.4% at a potential of −0.25 V vs. RHE. The catalytic activity of LC-CoOOH/CF was further analyzed by DFT calculations to determine the underlying reasons. The amorphous region of LC-CoOOH/CF exhibited the disordered atomic arrangement and surface dangling bonds, which provided abundant catalytic sites and facilitated the adsorption of NO3 − (Fig. 13e). Through the LSV test of anode EGOR (Fig. 13f), it was found that GA is the primary oxidation product at low potentials of 0.6–1.0 V vs. RHE, while FA became dominant at higher potentials of 1.4–1.6 V vs. RHE. Therefore, the selective generation of GA on Pd-NTs/NF could be achieved by electrochemical potential regulation during EGOR. Considering the practicality of the subsequent application, a co-production electrolysis system was further constructed with LC-CoOOH/CF as the cathode for NH3 production and Pd-NTs/NF as the anode for GA production. Compared with the NO3RR//OER system (Fig. 13g), it was found that the NO3RR//PET hydrolysate oxidation system could effectively lower energy consumption. Wang et al. [107] synthesized mesoporous Pd3Au thin films on Ni foam (mPd3Au/NF) for electrochemical upgrading recovery of nitrates and PET plastics (Entry 10, Table 4). The uniform mesoporous structure provided sufficient catalytic active sites and high conductivity for mPd3Au/NF, promoting the electronic transfer between active sites and reaction intermediates, resulting in the formation of NH3 and GA with an FE of 97.3% and 95.3% at 0.9 V vs. RHE (Entry 9, Table 4). Theoretical results showed that synergistic effects of Pd and Au optimized the adsorption energy of key intermediates *NOH and *OCH2–CH2OH on active sites and enhanced the bond energy of the C–C bond, thereby improving the activity and selectivity of NH3 and GA generation. Additionally, besides noble metals such as Au, low-cost transition metals alloyed with Pd can also adjust the lattice parameters, surface energy, and electronic structure of Pd and can effectively change the adsorption/desorption behavior of reactants and intermediates on the surface of the electrocatalysts, thereby improving catalytic activity and selectivity of Pd-based electrocatalysts [108,109]. Xu et al. [110] synthesized PdCu alloy metalene grown on Ni foam (PdCuene/NF) by a one-step solvothermal method and used it directly as the anode for the EGOR (Entry 11, Table 4). The counter electrode was treated with oxidation-electroreduction to convert it into the reconstituted PdCuene/NF (r-PdCuene/NF) material for the cathode NO3RR. Experimental and theoretical studies showed that the introduction of Cu and the formation of PdCu alloy could adjust the electronic structure of Pd atoms, facilitate efficient adsorption of EG, promote rapid conversion of toxic carbonyl intermediates, and lower desorption energy of GA from the catalyst surface. The PdCuene/NF could effectively convert EG to GA, and the FEmax was 92.1%. Under the synergistic effect of metalene array structure and alloying effect, the r-PdCuene/NF exhibited strong nitrate reduction activity, and the FEmax was 91.5%. By constructing the coupling electrolysis system of nitrate and PET hydrolysate, EG could be converted to GA at the anode and NO3 − could be converted to NH3 at the cathode. The FEs of NH3 and GA were both above 94%. Sun et al. [111] synthesized bimetallic PdCu mesoporous nanopores (MCs) as a bifunctional enzyme-catalyzed electrocatalyst for the simultaneous electrocatalytic upgrading of NO3 − wastewater and PET plastic waste (Entry 12, Table 4). PET-derived EG could be selectively electrooxidized into GA and FA by adjusting the anodic potential (FE >90%). 3.2 Lactic acid (LA) Polylactic acid (PLA) is a bio-based and biodegradable polyester, which is one of the candidate materials for replacing traditional petroleum-based plastics. Currently, the global production of biodegradable plastics is steadily increasing and is expected to reach 1.8 million tons by 2025. Due to its durability, transparency, and mechanical strength, PLA accounts for 32.2% of the total production of biodegradable plastics. Although PLA can undergo natural degradation, specific industrial composting conditions are required in the actual degradation process to completely degrade it, and the degradation process is slow. Moreover, the final products of PLA degradation primarily consist of CO2 and H2O, which will lead to greenhouse gas emissions and the waste of carbon resources. Therefore, utilizing electrochemical oxidation technology as an alternative approach to convert PLA into value-added chemicals represents a possible choice for its use [112–114]. Chen et al. [115] conducted hydrolysis of PLA to generate a solution suitable for direct electrolysis. They synthesized Ni2P/NF catalyst through electrochemical deposition and phosphide treatment for the electrocatalytic oxidation of PLA. The catalysts showed over 80% acetic acid (Hac) selectivity and nearly 100% LA conversion after continuous electrolysis for 7 h. The evolution of the catalyst was investigated through in-situ and ex-situ characterization, and it was observed that Ni2P transformed into γ-NiOOH with a loosely packed layer structure during the reaction process. The formation of γ-NiOOH played a crucial role as an active site in the electro-reforming process, which promoted the oxidation of LA. However, during the electro-oxidation of LA to Hac, excessive CO2 was also produced. To achieve a complete carbon cycle, Lan et al. [116] coupled the anodic oxidation of LA and the cathodic reduction of CO2 to utilize excess CO2, which not only produced valuable chemicals (FA) but also reduced energy consumption. They developed a nickel selenide nanosheet supported on nickel foam (NiSe2/NF) as an anode catalyst for electrocatalytic oxidation of PLA to Hac. They used Bi2O3 as the cathodic catalyst for the electro-reduction of CO2 to generate FA. In alkaline conditions, the NiSe2/NF catalyst could produce a current density of 100 mA cm−2 with an FE of 95% for Hac at a potential of 1.54 V vs. RHE, which was almost twice that of the NF carrier. Combining in-situ experiments and DFT calculations, it was shown that NiOOH promoted LA oxidation reaction by cutting the C–C bonds of LA to generate Hac. Combining the CO2RR to generate FA at the cathode, the sum of Faraday efficiency of carboxylic acid generation from cathode and anode reached 190% at 20 mA cm−2 during the whole electrolysis reaction, indicating that these materials have great potential for the electrochemical conversion of waste PLA and CO2. Based on the C3 structure of LA, the production of higher-value C3 products under mild conditions is of interest to avoid unwanted ways such as C–C bond cleavage occurring, which underscores the necessity for new chemical upcycling technology. Ma et al. [32] proposed a cascade catalytic strategy for the conversion of PLA plastic waste into value-added alanine under mild conditions (Fig. 14 a). Firstly, PLA plastic was depolymerized into hydrolysate using KOH. Subsequently, LA was pulsed electrooxidized into pyruvate by using PLA hydrolysate as the electrolyte. Finally, hydroxylamine (NH2OH), used as the nitrogen precursor, and pyruvate were electrochemically co-reduced to alanine. Considering that noble metal-based catalysts are suitable for selectively oxidizing alcohols at low voltages while avoiding undesirable C–C bond cleavage, they constructed a catalyst consisting of Ni(OH)2 nanosheets with Pd nanoparticles grown on Ni foam (Pd/Ni(OH)2/NF), which facilitated the selective conversion of LA to pyruvic acid. They reported that Pd catalysts were gradually transformed into palladium oxides (Pd–O or Pd2+ species) during the oxidation process, leading to deactivation of the catalyst. As the potential was scanned in reverse, the Pd–O could be reduced to form new active sites for LA oxidation at 1.0 V potential. To induce LA oxidation on fresh Pd surface, continuous oxidation of LA was achieved through an alternating potential (Fig. 14b). Repeating the sequence for 5 min (Fig. 14c) and 120 min, the current recorded under pulsed conditions demonstrated good reproducibility, indicating that periodic repetitive pulses could effectively regenerate new Pd surfaces. A titanium felt supported TiO2 nanorod (TiO2/TF) was designed as an electrocatalyst for the production of alanine. With the negative increase of potential, the yield of alanine increased, but the FE decreased sharply due to the large amount of hydrogen evolution at −0.4 V (Fig. 14d). The reaction pathway of alanine on TiO2/TF was investigated using NMR and in-situ FTIR. The conversion of pyruvate to alanine primarily involved two steps (Fig. 14e): (i) pyruvate spontaneously condenses with NH2OH to form an oxime intermediate and (ii) oxime is electrochemically reduced to alanine. The cascaded method was demonstrated for the conversion of real PLA plastic mixtures. After 98 h of electrolysis under pulsed conditions, a pyruvate yield of 81.5% and an FE of 82% were achieved. Subsequently, in the process of converting pyruvate to alanine, the yield of alanine was 84.7%, and FE was 85 %. Finally, TEA was conducted for the cascading strategy of utilizing PLA waste plastic as raw material for scaled-up production of alanine, with the results showing that conversion of 1 ton of PLA waste into alanine (5206 $ ton−1) and other value-added chemicals, such as K2SO4 (685 $ ton−1), H2 (2790 $ ton−1), and O2 (82.2 $ ton−1), could generate a net income of $1740, which indicated that the cascading strategy is favorable for economic return. Jia et al. [117] established a cascaded conversion chain from waste plastic to amino acids. The lactic acid solution obtained by the hydrolysis of PLA was converted into pyruvate by electrochemical oxidation, and the IrO2/Ti electrode was used as the catalyst for electrochemical oxidation. Subsequently, the pH value of the electrolyte was adjusted and nitrogen source was introduced. The obtained electrolyte was directly used for the reductive amination reaction catalyzed by N, S co-doped carbon nanosheets to generate alanine. Furthermore, wastes of PLA-based respirators, water bottles, and straws were further converted into alanine. The selectivity of LA monomer to alanine products was 76%, 81%, and 78%, respectively, which showed that the established tandem conversion pathway was selective for converting actual PLA waste plastics into value-added alanine products. 3.3 Monomer 1,4-butanediol (BDO) The engineering thermoplastic polybutylene terephthalate (PBT) is synthesized from TPA and BDO monomers. PBT has desirable properties including thermal stability, high electrical insulation, high mechanical strength, and good processability, making it widely used in packaging materials, bottles, fiber, and other industries. However, the use of PBT can lead to environmental pollution. PBT, which has attributes similar to PET, can be hydrolyzed into corresponding monomers in alkaline solutions allowing it to be converted into valuable products by electrocatalysis [5,118,119]. Liu et al. [33] used electrochemically activated nickel foam (NF) as an electrocatalyst for the upgrading and recycling of PBT waste plastics. Fig. 15 (a) illustrates the electro-corrosion mechanism of NF in NaCl solution. Firstly, Ni2+ is generated through anodic corrosion of NF with the assistance of Cl− anions. Subsequently, Ni2+ is electrochemically redeposited via reverse CV scanning. This cyclic process leads to the oxidation of newly deposited Ni, resulting in the formation of nano-sized NiO x H y on the surface of NF, which passivates and ensures uniform growth of the corrosion layer. The treated NF (T-NF) was used for the electrocatalytic conversion of BDO in PBT hydrolysate, enabling efficient electrocatalytically reforming into succinic acid (SA) with an FE of 93%.
