To investigate BDO oxidation reaction (BOR) behavior on T-NF, in-situ Raman spectroscopy was used to monitor the surface evolution of T-NF during OER (Fig. 15b) and BOR processes (Fig. 15c and d). Results demonstrated that NiOOH acted as a chemical oxidant to oxidize BDO, and could regenerate low-valent Ni after the reaction, which also provided an explanation for the catalytic activity of NiOOH prior to the initiation of OER by high-valence Ni4+. Furthermore, the presence of BDO impeded the appearance of signals associated with Ni–O vibrations before 1.70 V, indicating that the oxidation of BDO was accompanied by reduction of Ni3+ in NiOOH, thereby delaying the formation of NiOOH. DFT calculations and in-situ FTIR spectroscopy were combined to further determine the favorable pathway of BOR to SA. According to the DFT calculations (Fig. 15e), it could be observed that O–H bond cleavage in BDO to form OH(CH2)3–HCO* was an endothermic process with a ΔG value reaching 1.45 eV, which was the rate-determining step of BOR. Subsequently, OH(CH2)3–COOH* underwent cleavage on NiOOH with a ΔG value of 0.24 eV. Finally, the oxidation of the OH(CH2)3COOH* intermediate led to the formation of the final product SA, which was an exothermic process. To broaden the application range of T-NF, the electrochemical oxidation activity of T-NF towards other organic molecules (urea, glycerol, and methanol) was studied, yielding promising results. Xiong et al. [120] synthesized Mn-doped NDA nanosheets (NDA: 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid), a metal-organic framework (MOF), via ligand exchange method and used it for electrocatalytic oxidation of BDO to SA. The conversion of the doped layered hydroxide (d-LH) precursor to MOF promoted BDO oxidation while inhibiting the competitive OER. The results showed that MOF had a higher alcohol affinity for BDO than d-LH, while Mn doping into NiNDA leaded to electron accumulation at the Ni site, and the d-band center moved upward to facilitate spin-dependent charge transfer, which was beneficial to the oxidation of BDO. By coupling BOR and HER, the constructed two-electrode membrane electrode assembly (MEA) flow battery could obtain an industrial current density of 1.5 A cm−2@1.82 V at 50 °C, and a corresponding specific energy consumption of 3.68 kWh Nm−3 H2. Compared with traditional water electrolysis (∼5 kWh Nm−3 H2) for hydrogen production, the energy consumption was lower by more than 25%. Poly(butylene adipate-co-terephthalate) (PBAT), which is a biodegradable polyaliphatic-polyaromatic polyester composed of adipic acid (AA), TPA, and BDO, has excellent material properties and biodegradability as a polymer for packaging and film applications. However, the production of PBAT is carbon-intensive and mainly depends on the use of oil-based monomers. Therefore, upgrading and recycling of waste PBAT is necessary because its natural degradation is slow [121,122]. Pang et al. [123] used the BDO-alkali composite method to conduct the alkaline hydrolysis of PBAT. This hydrolysis process primarily aimed to cleave the ester bond between the fatty acid ester PBA and the aromatic ester PBT segment first, followed by alkaline-conditioned hydrolysis. Dipotassium terephthalate and dipotassium adipate were precipitated from the hydrolyzed solution, and the remaining solution was mainly composed of BDO, H2O, and KOH, which was used as the electrolyte for subsequent electrocatalytic oxidation. Subsequently, the nickel foam supported NiOOH catalyst (NiOOH/NF) was rapidly obtained through a two-step synthesis approach. The hydrolysis solution obtained via the BDO-alkali composite method underwent oxidation at the anode using NiOOH/NF electrocatalyst, referred to as BOR. This process enabled the BDO component in the PBAT hydrolysis product to be electro-catalytically reconstituted into a high-value SA, with a FE of 97.6%. Three reaction pathways from BOR to SA were explored by in-situ technology, and the optimal reaction pathway and reaction mechanism of BOR to SA were further determined by DFT calculation, which provided a feasible approach for the upgrading and recycling of post-consumer biodegradable PBAT plastics. Polybutylene succinate (PBS) is a biodegradable bio-plastic obtained by polymerizing BDO and SA. PBS has excellent mechanical properties and good heat resistance. Recycling waste PBS plastic to obtain SA is a possible process for its upgrading. As the main monomer of PBS, BDO can be oxidized to obtain SA, which is one of the key strategies for recycling waste PBS plastic. To improve the economy of electrocatalytic plastic recycling, Zhou et al. [124] designed a membrane-free co-electrolysis system to co-produce SA at the anode and cathode by co-electrolysis of PBS waste plastic and biomass-derived maleic acid (MA). The electrolysis reaction system used Cr3+-Ni(OH)2 as the electrocatalyst for the anode, while the cathode used PdCu as the electrocatalyst. The study found that the Cr3+ in Cr3+-Ni(OH)2/Cr3+-NiOOH acted as an “electron puller” by attracting electrons from Ni2+/Ni3+, resulting in electron deficiency on Ni2+/Ni3+ in Cr3+-Ni(OH)2/Cr3+-NiOOH, which accelerated the rate-determining step in the Ni2+/Ni3+ cycle. By using the co-product system, SA could be obtained simultaneously at the anode and cathode, and a SA yield of 3.02 g h−1 and an FE of 181.5 % could be obtained. Furthermore, a carbon dioxide-assisted sequential precipitation method was developed to obtain high-purity SA (purity 99%) and byproduct NaHCO3 solids from the electrolyte. 4 Commonality and design strategy of catalysts Research in upgrading waste plastics into high-value chemicals has mainly focused on producing small molecule monomers (diols or polyols) by hydrolysis that is followed by conversion of those products with electrochemical reactions. Non-noble metal-based catalysts have been used to promote the upgrading and conversion of small molecule alcohols in alkaline environments in which strategies for catalyst design or implementation tend to employ general concepts such as the exposure of structural and active sites to substrate or modification of the catalyst during the electrocatalytic process to obtain active sites [125]. Nickel-based catalysts (especially NiOOH) have been shown to be highly-active for transformation of monomers. However, monomers from plastics typically contain C–C bonds, and non-noble metal catalysts can cause excessive cleavage of C–C bonds, which is not conducive to achieving carbon recycling. Noble metal-based catalysts are usually chosen to maintain the C–C bond in reactants and to obtain high-value multi-carbon products. Therefore, noble metal-based catalysts are usually selected to maintain the C–C bond in the reactants to obtain high-value multi-carbon products. However, pure noble metal-based catalysts are severely limited by the high sensitivity of carbonyl intermediates, causing them to become inactive within a short period of time, with poor durability. Therefore, a possible strategy to improve the activity and durability of catalysts is by combining noble metals with non-noble metals to vary their structure and composition that affects electronic interactions and adsorption sites to allow the control of catalyst activity and robustness as a tradeoff [44,87,108,109]. 5 Direct upgrading of plastic waste via electrocatalysis The direct electrolysis of waste plastics to obtain high-value chemicals by electrocatalytic technology can avoid the pretreatment (hydrolysis) process of plastics. Li et al. [126] prepared cobalt selenide nanosheets on nickel foam (0.1CoSe2/NF) as a bifunctional catalyst for plastic electrochemical conversion assisted water electrolysis. Due to the ultra-thin thickness (3.5 nm), abundant edge active sites, large electrochemical active area, three-dimensional porous structure, and high conductivity of the 0.1-CoSe2/NF material, PLA electrooxidation and HER in a 1 M KOH electrolyte solution in continuous electrolysis for 30 h afforded acetic acid (HAc) with a conversion of PLA electrooxidation into HAc of about 87%. Moreover, the electrolytic cell assembled with 0.1-CoSe2/NF as both cathode and anode catalysts for simultaneous PLA electrolysis and hydrogen production was found to suppress OER by PLA oxidation and address the safety concern regarding gas crossover during water electrolysis. From the results, the conversion rate was lower than that of lactic acid monomers after hydrolysis [115], and the conversion was slow, which means that the process will be more time-consuming and energy-consuming than chemical-based methods. Current research on plastic upgrading and recycling mainly focuses on the value-added of plastic monomers generated during the pretreatment process, which may limit the development of direct production of value-added chemicals from raw plastic by electrocatalytic technology due to the following reasons. Firstly, the electrocatalytic reaction process is usually carried out in an electrolyte, so the liquid electrolyte is a necessary condition for the reaction. If the plastic is directly added to an electrolyte, the reaction system is generally inefficient for converting the plastic directly via electrocatalytic methods due to the inertness of the plastic and its limited solubility in aqueous electrolytes. Secondly, due to the vast variety of plastics in the real world, the cost of separating or sorting single-type plastic from waste is high and may not be practical due to the use of laminates and composites. Finally, the economic feasibility of plastic electrolysis under actual conditions, especially the cost of separating or classifying pure plastic from waste, should be evaluated [127]. Therefore, the goal is to be able to upgrade waste plastic directly through electrocatalytic technology, but presently, there are a number of milestones that will need to be achieved first related to polyester classification, specific pretreatment (mechanical, chemical), electrode design, electrode long-term performance, and product separation. Among the many different types of waste plastics, polyester forms are likely to be the first material that can be directly upgraded via electrocatalysis. 6 Conclusions and outlook To address the global plastic recycling and in considering the similarity between the basic components of plastics and petroleum-derived hydrocarbons, it is attractive to convert monomers derived from waste polyester plastics into high-value chemicals using renewable electricity. This review focused on upgrading and recycling processes of polyester plastics from the perspective of electrocatalytic technology. The latest research progress of electrocatalysis was discussed for different products and coupling systems, while reaction mechanisms and pathways were specifically analyzed based on the reaction system. Furthermore, the pretreatment process of waste plastics, the evaluation metrics of electrocatalytic reactions, and the subsequent product recovery were summarized. In short, the upgrading and recycling of waste plastics based on renewable electricity has good prospects for the future. However, there are still gaps between laboratory developments and industrial needs that need to be explored for realizing practical systems. (1) Pretreatment processes. As polyester waste plastics are extensively used in daily life, businesses often add dyes or other chemicals to the outer packaging plastic to identify their products for safety and health purposes as well to attract general consumers. Although the hydrolysis of polyester plastics is relatively straightforward, the subsequent electrolysis process, product separation and recycling become require development due to the presence of impurities (such as dyes or other chemicals), and this also leads to a decrease in the purity of potential value-added products. Therefore, it is essential to perform trials with suitable surrogates in the hydrolysate before electrolysis and to consider relevant methods or designs that remove such impurities. (2) Development of practical electrocatalysts. Currently, although most studies have achieved high conversion rates and high Faraday efficiencies under laboratory conditions, industrial production requires operation at high current densities. However, operating at high current densities not only leads to the presence of competitive reactions (OER and HER) in the reaction system, but also results in excessive oxidation of the target product. Additionally, the stability and durability of the catalysts are critical issues for industrial production. Therefore, further optimizing the design of the catalyst holds much importance. The following four points can be summarized: (i) explore more types of electrocatalysts, such as perovskites, high-entropy alloys, and single-atom catalysts; (ii) enhance the reaction activity of the catalyst through crystal surface engineering, surface modification, and doping techniques; (iii) identify and regulate the active sites for electrochemical conversion and competitive reactions of waste plastic monomers based on specific reaction types, thus achieving fundamental separation between main and side reactions; (iv) perform theoretical calculations to identify, rank, select, and prepare catalysts. In summary, future research should focus on designing electrocatalysts with high stability and activity at high current densities to meet industrial production needs. (3) Design of electrolytic cell devices. At present, reaction systems for electrochemical upgrading and recycling of waste plastic monomers are primarily focused on standard three-electrode electrolytic cells (single cell and H-type electrolytic cells), flow cells, and MEA electrolytic cells. However, there have been few studies that extend the performance evaluation of catalysts to larger-scale electrolysis devices. Therefore, to meet the demands of large-scale industrial production, it is necessary to systematically study the design of electrolytic cells, the combination of catalysts, the design of ion exchange membranes, and the reaction environments. In addition, the influence of parameters under actual operating conditions (such as flow rate and liquid supply mode) should be explored through the combination of simulations. (4) Applicability of pairing reactions. The upgrading and recycling of waste plastics by electrocatalytic technology primarily aims to obtain high-value chemicals through the electrochemical oxidation of depolymerization monomers. The cathode mainly consists of the reactions such as HER, ORR, CO2RR, and NO3RR, and are coupled with the anode to form the electrochemical reaction system. Although pairing reactions have broad application prospects, practical testing is required to address issues for the coupled system such as the inability to simultaneously control the voltage of both anode and cathode in a two-electrode system and to determine whether the resulting products have high value. Future research could consider obtaining high-value chemicals containing C–N and C–S by coupling the anode and cathode during the entire reaction process. (5) Product separation. The separation of products obtained from the conversion of waste plastic monomers is a crucial objective for industrial production. Currently, product separation primarily relies on differences in physical properties such as boiling point, distribution coefficient or solvent solubility, resulting in high costs during industrial production. Therefore, it is imperative to develop cost-effective separation methods suitable for electrochemical industrial production systems, such as those that use membranes. (6) Economic feasibility. To achieve the industrialization of converting waste plastics into chemicals, it is necessary to conduct TEA of the designed electrolysis system. Currently, TEA is still at the preliminary analysis stage, with limited aspects being examined. Therefore, it is necessary to simulate the TEA of industrial production systems critically and in detail to better estimate the economic feasibility of a process. To sum up, electrochemical upgrading and recycling of waste plastic monomers into high-value chemicals can serve as an effective solution to the environmental issues caused by spent plastics. By designing the reaction system and studying the reaction mechanism, high-selectivity electrocatalyst can be designed based on the reaction pathway to achieve targeted conversion of waste plastic monomers, which will play an important role in establishing an eco-friendly environment. Haoye Wang is currently a doctoral candidate in the group of Prof. Xinhua Qi, College of Environmental Science and Engineering at Nankai University. He is presently engaged in design and synthesis of efficient and robust electrocatalysts for applications in waste recycling. Richard Lee Smith Jr. is a Professor in the Graduate School of Environmental Studies (GSES)/GP-RSS, Tohoku University, Japan. He obtained his PhD in Chemical Engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology (USA) in 1985 (Amyn S. Teja, Supervisor). His research focuses on developing green chemical processes with solvothermal and hydrothermal methods. He has published more than 300 scientific papers and is author of “Introduction to Supercritical Fluids” published by Elsevier in 2013 and Co-editor for the Book Series “Biofuels and Biorefineries” (Zhen Fang, Editor-In-Chief) published by Springer-Nature. Professor Smith is Asia Regional Editor for the Journal of Supercritical Fluids. Xinhua Qi is a distinguished professor of College of Environmental Science and Engineering at Nankai University. Prof. Qi received his B.S. in environmental chemistry from Nankai University in 1998, and Ph.D. in environmental science from Nankai University in 2003. He worked as a JSPS Postdoctoral Fellow at Tohoku University (Sendai, Japan) from Oct. 2006 to Nov 2010. He was promoted to a full professor in 2011 at Nankai University. His research interest mainly focuses on green processes for the production of value-added materials and chemicals from organic solid wastes. He has published more than 160 peer reviewed scientific papers, and these papers have been cited over 6300 times with H index 44. He also has co-authored over 20 patents, 5 books and 3 book chapters on environmental engineering and biomass resources utilization. His research work has been awarded 2 items of first-class prizes and 1 item of second-class prizes of provincial and ministerial level. Prof. Qi has been selected as leading talent in the National Ten Thousand Talents Plan, Shennong Talent Plan from Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, and was supported by the Outstanding Youth Science Foundation of Tianjin.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysis offers efficient and targeted conversion of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics to chemical products under ambient temperature and pressure conditions. This review provides analysis of research on electrochemical upgrading of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics published from 2021 to present. Factors for assessing upgrading of waste polyester plastics include alkaline hydrolysis pretreatment, indices of electrochemical reaction process (activity, stability, and techno-economic analysis), separation, and product recovery. Types of depolymerization monomers and their value-added products are summarized along with electrocatalytic mechanisms and reaction pathways. Notably, cathode coupled reactions offer significant value for anodic waste plastic oxidation during electrolysis processes. Development of bifunctional electrocatalysts can reduce the cost of coupled systems and complexity of the electrolyzer. Upgrading and recycling of waste plastic monomers using electrocatalytic technology should undergo downstream processing to form high-value products containing C–N and C–S derived functional groups obtained from depolymerized monomers. Electrochemical conversion and upgrading of monomers derived from waste polyester plastics can contribute to industrialization and global economies and help to realize environmental sustainability.
